sub_title: Docent 1ste graads Aardrijkskunde at College Hageveld
summary:
Bram is project consultant with Balance as an up and coming projectmanager.I am a graduated socio-technical engineer in Irrigation and Watermanagement from Wageningen University in the Netherlands. I have gained national and international experience having studied and worked on embankments projects in the Netherlands, Sand storage dams in Kenya and an feasibility study for irrigation in village in South Africa. 
I always look for the technical and social perspectives in my work. The art of using both perspectives is key for realising projects to ensure the project's intended long term effects. This is true for the projects in the water sector but is also true for any other industry.

school.name: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Van Hall Larenstein University of Applied Sciences

awards.title: Winner WOW Young Professional Challenge 2014
awards.description: Winning concept of the WOW challenge, an initiative by Rijkswaterstaat, Dutch Water Boards, Provinces and munincipalities. The question was how to improve the protection against flooding in the Netherlands. Our concept is to invest in resillience rather than just protection against flooding. This is achieved by creating a concsiousness within the Dutch community of the inherent risks that come with living below sea level. This is done along 3 themes: concsiousness, reinforcment and cooperation. The ideas are relatively easy to implement as they connect to existing networks and infrastructure rather than creating new. The concept was credited for its innovation in its thinking and the possibility to implement the measures on a short term.

projects.title: Land Use Planning IJburg & Zeeburgereiland, Munincipality of Amsterdam
projects.description: Tthe final phase of building IJburg, Amsterdam's biggest city expansion project; build on new land in the IJsselmeer. This final phase of construction entails the development of the final plots, preparing these plots for construction, laying down amenities and construction of infrastructure ( roads, lighting, sidwalks and sewage). My role within this project is as assistent project manager. My role is to coordinate with the contractors on the plots and infrastructure and improving the project management processes.

projects.title: Dredging and embankment protection project along the Broeker-, Trek- en Purmerringvaart (K11)
projects.description:
Assistent project manager of the project that aims to restore accessibility of the Broeker-, Trek- en Purmerringvaart by dredging around 5 km of canal. Furthermore the projects includes the reconstruction of  the embankment protection along the canal. WIthin the urban areas these are restored using steel sheet piling and in the rural areas with a wooden construction built in a fashion that enables the creation of new habitat.
Timelapse of the project: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5gw8r0Aqc9g

projects.title: Minor in Environmental Governance
projects.description:
Minor: Environmental Governance
Consisting of courses covering the entire spectrum of environmental governance: A judicial background to environmental matters and the way cities are developed nowadays. These two are brought together in the course on Environmental Quality and Governance. Here natural sciences and social sciences are used for a policy simulation game. This minor is takes a few steps back and looks at environmental issues from a policy perspective. Combining this with my more technological focussed education at Van Hall Larenstein, the socio-technical approach from the first year of the MIL programme makes me an all-round professional that is able to communicate with a wide range of other professionals.

contributors.headline: Docent 1ste graads Aardrijkskunde at College Hageveld

projects.title: MSc Thesis: Designing Smallholder Irrigation in the Eastern Cape
projects.description: Due to pensions, remittances and migration and other reasons land has been increasingly left fallow around the village of Guquka (Hebinck & Lent, 2007, p. 220). Now the village, by mouth of an association of residents has expressed a wish to establish an irrigation scheme to facilitate commercial crop production.  Standardized irrigation design practices, or blueprints, are deemed unsuitable for the local context. Whether larger irrigation schemes or for the small rural villages, a system needs to be adapted and designed to suit the local conditions. So farmers need to develop, together with scholars and professionals, an approach for developing an irrigation system. But the process which will bring them from A to B is still unclear. To actually build an irrigation scheme requires several types of infrastructural artifacts such as canals, division structures, a diversion structure and/or a pump. Besides this a management system must be in place to take care of maintaining the infrastructure and operating the system as well as tackling any conflicts. As of yet there is little knowledge on what options are open to the farmers, what options are desirable and feasible. Furthermore it is unclear  how to assess these criteria or how to approach the design process and to which end. This research hopes to contribute to this lack of understanding by actively engaging in the design processes.

contributors.headline: Docent 1ste graads Aardrijkskunde at College Hageveld

projects.title: Internship for Edukans/Ex-change
projects.description:
Bram van der Horst accompanied by Simon Mutiso and Catherine Pius, both Kenyan students, conducted a research in Kitui, Kenya. This report is the result of that research and it's goal is to give the SASOL foundation, a NGO which is focussed on developmentcooperation, advice on how to proceed with their  MPC-South project and to show other students a brief look into an internship abroad. The SASOL foundation started  a project which was named MPC-South, they want to construct demonstration farms and training centers there. Water is needed for all of the employees, trainees and livestock and the project area is located in one of the most arid parts of Kenya. Therefore SASOL asked Water management team 172 to conduct research into:

-The properties of 5 predetermined build locations for sand dams in the seasonal stream, which borders the project area. The research contains topics such as geology, stream configuration, material availability, site accessibility and bank condition.Furthermore for each of the five sites a initial spillway  was designed.
 
- A pipeline for connecting the sand dams to the area where the offices, demo farms and training centres are to be built. 

- The possibility of catching rainwater on roofs and subsequently storing it for further use within MPC-South. 


As Edukans/Ex-Change have a strong focus on educating of the Kenyan students with whom a Dutch students works, I trained the Kenyan students in the use of a theodolite, which was required for the pipeline and spillway design cases and gave instructions on how to calculate possible harvestable water from roofs and the spillways using the Manning formula.

contributors.headline: Docent 1ste graads Aardrijkskunde at College Hageveld

projects.title: Thesis at Arcadis, Mobility division - Research into the Optimal Relation between Lifecyclecosts and Available Embankments
projects.description: Each soil type reacts differently to loads. Sand settles very little but soils such as peat or clay react to a load by shrinking or in other words settling. When a road or embankment needs to be constructed on such a low load bearing soil several problems present themselves. Settlement problems, building time, building costs, O&M costs. These all depend on the technique for constructing the embankment. Therefore we did research into the optimal embankment for a low load bearing soil type through a case study, a newly build road between Hoek van Holland and Westerlee. This research looks into what options are available for engineers when it comes to creating an embankment, this included tried and tested methods but also newly developed methods such as Smartsoils. We looked at these methods through different glasses, or in other words we made a multi-criteria analysis where for different weight sets, representing different stakeholders, we could look at the opinions of these different stakeholders on the techniques. We then used this as input for our modelling exercise. The results from how a road could be built, was then input for a cost calculation but now focussing on lifecyclecosts instead of building costs, which is traditionally done. We concluded that a more expensive technique with less O&M does not weigh up to a cheaper building method with more O&M.

projects.title: Internship at Dura Vermeer
projects.description: The internship was at Dura Vermeer in Beuningen, Netherlands. Here I worked on a contest set up by the Ministry for Infrastructure and Environment called: "less annoyance when renovating steel bridges", preparing projects and I did a literature study into the possibilities of Cradle2Cralde within the soil and water engineering sector.

profile_positions.description:
EWB-NL was contacted by CAMAAY (Cameroon Association of Active Youths) to provide technical assistance regarding the supply of drinking water.

The drinkingwater infrastructure in Oku, Cameroon, has been built about 30 years ago. The infrastructure is now starting to collapse and water quality and quantity is intermittent and only provides water for part of the population. 


http://www.ewbnl.org/water-management-cameroon/

As a project consultant for Balance Project Solutions, I contribute to the overall succes of Integral Project Management, Contractmanagement, Tendering and Integral area development on a project or consulting basis. After participating in an intensive month long course on project management I have been involved in the following:

- Assistent projectmanager IJburg and Zeeburgereiland for the munincipality of Amsterdam

profile_positions.description: The context of any project is often as important as the technical aspects. In my role as 'Omgevingsmanager' I am responsible for the context of the project:  stakeholder management, analysing legislation, permits and communication both internally and externally.

Herewith I learn the trade of the projectmanagement by gaining first hand experience as a projectleader.
